bestBHT.bht: Jesus, the Master, surprised His disciples by humbly taking on the role of a servant and washing their feet. It was customary in the East to wash the feet of guests, but Jesus went beyond expectations. He washed their feet in a basin, even attending to the feet of Judas. This act exemplified His deep humility and love, and served as a powerful lesson on serving others. By washing their feet, Jesus symbolically cleansed their lives and emphasized the importance of humility and selflessness.

Henry Alford: The context seems to show that He had washed the feet of one or more before the incident of the next verse.
The words, 'began to wash,' might merely express His doing something unusual and unlooked for.
The bason, viz. the vessel usually at hand for such purposes.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: wash. Beyond all doubt the feet of Judas were washed, as of
Albert Barnes: It was uniformly the office of a servant to wash the feet of guests.
It became a matter of necessity where they traveled without shoes, and where they reclined on couches at meals.
The disciples were [...] lying with their feet extended from the table, so that Jesus could easily have access to them.
Marvin Vincent: A bason [νιπτηρα] . Only here in the New Testament. From niptw, to wash.
John Calvin: These words express the design of Christ, rather than the outward act...
Philip Schaff: It is impossible not to mark the minuteness with which each separate part of the wonderful work of condescension he would describe is here recorded by the Evangelist.

According to the usages of the East, rendered necessary at once by the dusty nature of the roads and the imperfect covering afforded by sandals, it was customary for the master of a house, when receiving guests, to provide them with water to wash their feet.
Here Jesus, the Master of the feast, becomes Himself the servant.
Archibald T. Robertson: Poureth (βαλλε). Vivid present again. Literally, 'putteth' (as in verse John 13:2, βαλλω)."
Began to wash (ηρξατο νιπτειν). Back to the aorist again as with διεζωσεν (verse John 13:4). Νιπτω was common for washing parts of the body like the hands or the feet."
Wherewith (ω). Instrumental case of the relative ο.
John Gill: This custom of washing the feet was not used by the Jews at their passover, nor at their private entertainments, or common meals, but at the reception of strangers or travellers, which were just come off of a journey, whereby they had contracted dirt and filth, and was a servile work, never performed by superiors to their inferiors, but by inferiors to superiors.

But what a surprising instance of humility and condescension is this, that Christ, the Lord and master, should wash the feet of his disciples, when it was their proper work and business to have washed his?

Having washed their feet, he wipes them clean; which may design the purity of the lives and conversations of the saints in general, and of the ministers of the Gospel in particular, whose feet are beautiful when shod with the preparation of the Gospel of peace, and their conversations are as become the Gospel they preach.
John Wesley: Into the basin — A large vessel was usually placed for this very purpose, wherever the Jews supped.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, Jesus began to wash the feet of His disciples. This act may have been anticipated by the disciples, as Jesus had already washed the feet of others before this incident. The washing was done using a basin, which was a vessel commonly used for such purposes. It is worth noting that Jesus washed the feet of Judas as well, illustrating His deep humility and love. This act of washing feet was typically performed by a servant, and Jesus, being the Master of the feast, took on the role of a servant. The custom of washing feet was common in the East to cleanse the dirt and filth accumulated from travel. By washing their feet, Jesus not only physically cleansed them, but also symbolically demonstrated the purity of their lives and the need for humility among His disciples.

Jesus surprised His disciples by taking on the role of a servant and washing their feet. This act of humility was unusual and unexpected, as it was typically done by a servant. Jesus washed their feet in a basin, a vessel used for this purpose. Even Judas, the one who would betray Him, had his feet washed. This symbolic act demonstrated the necessity of humility and highlighted Jesus' love and selflessness. By washing their feet, Jesus exemplified the purity of their lives and the importance of serving others.

Jesus, the Master, surprised His disciples by humbly taking on the role of a servant and washing their feet. It was customary in the East to wash the feet of guests, but Jesus went beyond expectations. He washed their feet in a basin, even attending to the feet of Judas. This act exemplified His deep humility and love, and served as a powerful lesson on serving others. By washing their feet, Jesus symbolically cleansed their lives and emphasized the importance of humility and selflessness.

In an unexpected act of humility, Jesus, the Master, surprised His disciples by washing their feet. This was a servant's task, but Jesus willingly performed it. Using a basin, He cleansed their feet, including those of Judas. This act of condescension demonstrated His deep love and served as a powerful lesson on humility and serving others. By washing their feet, Jesus not only physically cleansed them but also emphasized the importance of purity in their lives and the need for selfless acts of service.

In an unexpected act, Jesus, as the Master, astonishingly took on the role of a servant, washing the feet of His disciples. He used a basin for this task, demonstrating His humility and love. Even the feet of Judas received His cleansing touch. This act served as a powerful lesson on humility and selflessness, highlighting the importance of serving others. By washing their feet, Jesus symbolically purified their lives, reflecting the need for purity and the transformative power of humble service.
